title: Tesla soars on delivery numbers -- company delivered 88,400 vehicles in Q1
summary:
Tesla reported on Thursday that it delivered approximately 88,400 vehicles in the first quarter of 2020, beating expectations.
Both numbers beat estimates: Analysts had expected combined deliveries of 68,674 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles, and combined deliveries of 11,234 Model S and X vehicles, as of Wednesday.
Without the COVID-19 related shutdowns, the analysts' consensus view was that Tesla could have delivered 95,528 vehicles, including 81,478 combined Model 3 and Model Y vehicles, and 14,050 combined Model S and Model X cars.
For the period ending March 31, Tesla said it produced about 103,000 vehicles total, including 15,390 Model S and X, and 87,282 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles.
In the year-ago first quarter, Tesla delivered 63,000 vehicles, including 50,900 Model 3 vehicles and 12,100 Model S and X cars.

title: IMPERFECT UNION: How Jessie and John Fremont Mapped the West, Invented Celebrity, and Helped Cause the Civil War
summary:
But the most important factor in his fame may have been the person who made it all possible: his wife, Jessie Benton Frémont.
In 1856, the famous couple strategized as John became the first-ever presidential nominee of the newly established Republican Party.
With rare detail and in consummate style, Steve Inskeep tells the story of a couple whose joint ambitions and talents intertwined with those of the nascent United States itself.
Together, John and Jessie Frémont took parts in events that defined the country and gave rise to a new, more global America.
In Imperfect Union, as Inskeep navigates these deeply transformative years through Jessie and John’s own union, he reveals how the Frémonts’ adventures amount to nothing less than a tour of the early American soul.

title: Report: Tesla to furlough employees, cut pay due to COVID-19
summary:
Tesla will reportedly cut salaries and furlough hourly workers a month after its CEO Elon Musk called the coronavirus panic "dumb."
The EV manufacturer will furlough employees who cannot work from home and those who aren't performing essential tasks at its plants, according to an internal company email obtained by CNN Business.
Starting Monday, most U.S. employees will receive a pay cut of 10%, while some senior staffers will see pay reductions of 20% to 30%, CNN Business reports.
The automaker's Shanghai factory temporarily shut down at the end of January but reopened in early February.

title: 21 Bay Area Cities To Increase Minimum Wage In 2020
summary:
While the state minimum wage is set to hit $12 an hour, many cities — most of which already have higher wages due to local measures — are increasing their minimum wages on top of that figure.
Statewide, California's minimum wage has been increasing $1 each year since 2017.
It will reach $12 an hour starting in 2020, and $15 an hour in 2023.
The federal minimum wage has remained at $7.25 an hour since 2009.

title: Most Walkable U.S. Cities 2020: How Fremont Ranks
summary:
FREMONT, CA — Walk Score, a company of real estate website Redfin, released on Monday its list of most walkable cities in the U.S.
For comparison, the top-ranked walkable city was New York City with a score of 88.3.
In addition to New York City, San Francisco and Boston are ranked as the most walkable cities in the U.S. in 2020, receiving scores of 87.4 and 82, respectively.
To determine the most walkable cities, Walk Score measures the walkability of any address by analyzing hundreds of walking routes to nearby amenities.
Walk Score also measures pedestrian friendliness by analyzing population density and road metrics such as block length and intersection density.

title: Who Will Serve Dublin, Fremont, Livermore? ALCO District 1 Debate
summary:
ALAMEDA COUNTY, CA — One of the most important political debates impacting Alameda County residents living in the cities of Dublin, Livermore, Fremont and nearby unincorporated areas happens Jan. 12, 2020.
For more than two decades, the District 1 seat on the Alameda County Board of Supervisors has been held by the same man.
Current District 1 Supervisor Scott Haggerty announced earlier this year he will not seek re-election when his current term expires in January 2021.
The long-time supervisor has held the post since November 1996 and is serving his sixth (and final) four-year term.
Fremont City Councilmember Vinnie Baker, Dublin Mayor David Haubert, Dublin City Councilmember Melissa Hernandez, and District 10 State Senator Bob Wieckowski are the four candidates on the March 3, 2020 Presidential Primary Election ballot vying for the District 1 seat.

title: City Of Fremont Hosts Census 2020 Kickoff Summit
summary:
From the City of Fremont:Posted on December 15, 2019The City of Fremont and Mayor Lily Mei hosted the Census 2020 Kickoff Summit on December 10, 2019 at Fremont City Hall.
As Census 2020 approaches, this meeting served as a springboard to present an overview of the importance of Census 2020 for the Fremont community and to provide for a strategy building session between leaders from community-based organizations, faith-based organizations, the business community, and elected officials to ensure that each Fremont resident is counted.
Census 2020 presents new challenges as the first digital Census and an increased public fear of the federal government.
The City of Fremont will use the information gathered at the Kickoff Summit to inform Census outreach activities and will continue reaching out to community organizations to serve as a resource and partner when the Census count begins in March 2020.
For more information about the City's Census 2020 efforts, contact Management Analyst Amanda Gallo by email or 510-284-4016.

title: Amazon says no plans for Fremont operation, but city documents say otherwise
summary:
Amazon says no plans for Fremont operation, but city...Planning documents recently filed in Fremont recommend the city approve parking for a new Amazon.com fulfillment center, and city officials have met with the company to discuss its plans — but Amazon won’t say whether it will open a facility there.
Fremont planner Courtney Pal said city officials met with the property owner and Amazon representatives in November to review how the parking area would be used.
“We don’t have any news to share about plans for (an operations) building in the area,” an Amazon spokeswoman said.
The Amazon spokeswoman disputed the characterization of the project as a “fulfillment center” in the planning documents, which were filed by the developer, Pacific Commons Owner.
The report noted that UPS has leased the separately owned but adjacent 815,000-square-foot Pacific Commons Industrial Center.

title: Fremont police reunite young girl found in park with parents
summary:
FREMONT (KRON) – Authorities have reunited a young child with her parents after finding the child on Tuesday afternoon at a park, according to the Fremont Police Department.
Around 3:06 p.m., police arrived at the Crandall Creek Park on Wabash River Place after receiving reports of a child found.
Police say the child is about two-years-old.
Officers say the mother arrived at the park after being alerted on social media.

title: Fremont to place boulders to stop homeless from parking RVs near Tesla
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — For the people who’ve made their homes along a frontage road near Tesla and other multibillion-dollar companies in Fremont, the area soon will be off-limits to their RVs, trailers and cars.
Seeking to put an end to all parking there, Fremont plans to place boulders along a portion of the road in the city’s busy industrial district.
“They’re picking on us,” Tony Zamora, 41, said Friday, standing outside of his trailer along Kato Road, where he’s been living for several months.
However, homeless people and truckers alike will need to find a new place to park very soon, it seems.
He also thinks the city issuing tickets to homeless folks over things such as expired tags is punitive and unnecessary.

title: Fremont Is The Happiest City In The United States: Report
summary:
The personal finance website WalletHub recently released its 2020's Happiest Cities in America, and Fremont landed at the top of the list.
At the other end of the rankings, Detroit, Michigan, finished as the least happy city in the United States.

title: 74-Year-Old Woman Arrested: Fremont Police
summary:
FREMONT, CA — Fremont Police say they have arrested a 74-year-old woman on suspicion of driving under the influence (DUI) following hit-and-run crashes involving parked vehicles and poles Monday evening.
The crashes happened shortly before 6 p.m. in a parking lot near the intersection of Paseo Padre Parkway and Walnut Avenue.
A caller said that a Subaru Outback had hit a pole and then backed into a parked vehicle.
Other callers reported that the Subaru hit another pole and vehicle in the parking lot, and the driver seemed disoriented.
She was arrested and booked into the Fremont Jail for suspected DUI and hit-and-run.

summary:

title: Fremont Man Killed In Crash ID'd
summary:
FREMONT, CA — The Contra Costa County coroner's office confirmed the identity Monday of a Fremont man who died Saturday from injuries suffered in a solo-vehicle crash in Hercules.
Daniel Coco, 44, suffered major injuries at about 12:40 p.m. Saturday after his pickup truck drove off eastbound Interstate Highway 80 near state Highway 4 into a field near the interchange and overturned.
According to the California Highway Patrol, Coco was the vehicle's only occupant.
People with information on the crash can contact the Contra Costa-area CHP office in Martinez at (925) 646-4980.

title: Two Purses Grabbed In Fremont: Police
summary:
FREMONT, CA — Two women have been the victims of a purse snatching or attempted snatching in Fremont Monday evening and Tuesday.

The description of the man who grabbed the purse is vague: a Black man with a medium build, around 6' to 6'2, and possibly wearing a beanie.

title: Recycle Your Christmas Tree In Fremont
summary:
FREMONT, CA — Fremont makes it easy to have your Christmas tree composted — just kick it to the curb.
First, a reminder that Christmas trees are only compostable if they are free of all decorations, tinsel, nails, and tree stands, including wooden stands nailed to the bottom of the trunk.
Flocked trees contain fire retardant and cannot be composted.
Curbside recycling:Dec. 30 through Jan. 10, 2020If your tree is less than 6 feet in length, place the whole tree in the gutter on your collection dayIf your tree is over 6 feet in length, cut the tree in half and place both halves in the gutter on your collection dayMake sure your tree is in the gutter, not on the sidewalkGreen Organics Cart:Cut compostable tree so that pieces fit loosely in your green organics cart with the lid closedPlace the cart at the curb on your scheduled collection dayGarbage Cart:If your tree has flocking or is otherwise not compostable, cut it up so pieces fit loosely in your black garbage cart with the lid closedPlace the black garbage cart at the curb on your scheduled collection dayFor more information, contact the Fremont Environmental Services Division at 510-494-4570.

title: California Minimum Wage Workers Get A Raise In 2020
summary:
CALIFORNIA — A new calendar year means a boost in the paychecks of minimum-wage American workers in more than 20 states, including California, where new minimum wage standards take effect in 2020.
In California, the 2020 minimum wage rate of $12 an hour for businesses with 25 employees or fewer and $13 an hour for larger companies takes effect on Jan. 1.
The federal minimum wage rate has remained unchanged at $7.25 an hour since 2009, but state legislatures — and, in some cases, voters themselves through ballot measures — have approved minimum wage increases.
Several Bay Area cities have passed a higher minimum wage, including San Francisco, where minimum wage is $15.59.
The highest of the new rates is in Washington State, where a 2016 voter-approved ballot initiative called for a $13.50 minimum wage floor in 2020, nearly twice the federal minimum wage.

title: Fremont Planning Commission to consider new homes in Niles, Mission San Jose
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — The Fremont Planning Commission on Thursday will review two housing proposals: one to build five homes across from a historic plant nursery in Niles and the other to put up 16 homes in the Mission San Jose district.
The proposals are in the early stages, and both the commission and City Council must decide whether they offer enough community benefits to warrant eventual approval and a general plan amendment.
A landowner, Yusef Attari, and an applicant, Hannah Chiu of Hogan Land Services, want to develop a vacant, 0.89-acre parcel at 36400 Niles Blvd.
The commission also will consider an application by Ray Lincoln, who owns two long-vacant lots totaling about 1.1 acres at 43401 and 43431 Ellsworth St., where developer Robson Homes of San Jose proposes to build 16 single-family homes.
The Fremont Planning Commission hearing is scheduled for 7 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 23, in the City Council Chambers, located at 3300 Capitol Ave., Building A.

title: Driver Charged In Fremont Hit-And-Run That Killed Facebook Employee
summary:
FREMONT (CBS SF) – Charges of felony vehicular manslaughter and hit-and-run have been filed against a Stanislaus County man related to the death of a bicyclist in August, the Fremont Police Department announced Saturday.
The fatality happened just before 5 a.m. on Aug. 28, when 28-year-old Fremont resident Kiranjot Deol was riding to his job at Facebook in Menlo Park.
Charges were filed against the driver, Ceres resident Rosendo Cruz Vargas, 25, after a lengthy investigation.
According to Deol’s LinkedIn profile, he had worked as a software engineer at Facebook since 2013.
“We were incredibly saddened to hear of Kiranjot’s passing,” Facebook spokesman Anthony Harrison said in August following the death.

If your tree is less than 6 feet in length, place the whole tree in the gutter on your collection day.
If your tree is over 6 feet in length, cut the tree in half and place both halves in the gutter on your collection day.

title: Full Pink Supermoon: How To See April's Bright Orb In Fremont
summary:
FREMONT, CA — If the weather cooperates in Fremont, the third supermoon of the year is worth getting out of your house to view Tuesday night.
The April full moon, also known as the "full pink moon," is the largest of four consecutive supermoons.
And despite its moniker, the April full pink supermoon is not a rosy orb.
It's called a pink moon because the April full moon closely corresponds to the emergence of the bright pink phlox flowers.
Though the February full moon's supermoon status was questioned, astronomers and astrologists agree the March, April and May full moons qualify for the designation.

title: Tesla Shares Rally Nearly 60% Over Seven Straight Sessions
summary:
(Bloomberg) -- Tesla Inc. shares are poised to mark the biggest seven-day gain since 2013, after Credit Suisse upgraded the electric-car company on Tuesday, saying the coronavirus crisis has handed it an edge over legacy automakers.
Shares of the Model 3 maker rose as much as 14% in New York on Tuesday, putting them on track for a nearly 60% climb in the course of its longest win streak since mid October.
Coronavirus-related market gyrations led Tesla shares to drop as much as a 61% from a record high on Feb. 19.
“There is some clear optimism from the bulls,” Wedbush analyst Dan Ives wrote to clients on Monday.
China production and demand appear poised for a significant rebound and should be a key growth driver over the coming quarter, he said.

title: Tesla soars on delivery numbers -- company delivered 88,400 vehicles in Q1
summary:
Tesla reported on Thursday that it delivered approximately 88,400 vehicles in the first quarter of 2020, beating expectations.
Both numbers beat estimates: Analysts had expected combined deliveries of 68,674 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles, and combined deliveries of 11,234 Model S and X vehicles, as of Wednesday.
Without the COVID-19 related shutdowns, the analysts' consensus view was that Tesla could have delivered 95,528 vehicles, including 81,478 combined Model 3 and Model Y vehicles, and 14,050 combined Model S and Model X cars.
For the period ending March 31, Tesla said it produced about 103,000 vehicles total, including 15,390 Model S and X, and 87,282 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles.
In the year-ago first quarter, Tesla delivered 63,000 vehicles, including 50,900 Model 3 vehicles and 12,100 Model S and X cars.

title: The Coronavirus Pandemic Could Be a Perfect Storm for Tesla
authors: Fool Since I Write About Consumer Goods
Whatever Else Piques My Interest. Follow Me On Twitter To See My Latest Articles
For Commentary On Hot Topics In Retail
summary:
Even as Tesla stock has already plunged more than 53% since the coronavirus crash began around Feb. 20, it could still have a lot further to fall.
Recession and luxury don't mixThere's no question that Tesla vehicles are a luxury product, renowned for their high performance and priced similarly to other high-end vehicles.
Electric vehicle (EV) sales are sensitive to gas prices since the potential cost savings of EVs rise as gas prices go up.
High fuel costs also help explain why Tesla's top U.S. market is in California, where gas prices are among the steepest in the nation.
Tesla stock still looks priced for perfection, and it now faces supply challenges, a demand squeeze, and the specter of lower gas prices.

For comparison, the top-ranked walkable city was New York City with a score of 88.3.
In addition to New York City, San Francisco and Boston are ranked as the most walkable cities in the U.S. in 2020, receiving scores of 87.4 and 82, respectively.
To determine the most walkable cities, Walk Score measures the walkability of any address by analyzing hundreds of walking routes to nearby amenities.
Walk Score also measures pedestrian friendliness by analyzing population density and road metrics such as block length and intersection density.

summary:
FREMONT — A California Highway Patrol officer has been charged with sexually assaulting a 16-year-old girl, authorities said Monday.
The Alameda County District Attorney’s Office Monday charged 34-year-old Brian Watkins, of Fremont, with three counts of unlawful sexual assault against a minor, after Fremont police arrested him last week following a months-long investigation.
Fremont police said they began investigating Watkins in July 2019, after receiving a report of “alleged sexual misconduct involving Watkins” and a teenaged girl.
Watkins “began communicating and having a sexual relationship with the victim when she was 16 years old,” Fremont police said in a statement Monday afternoon.
Jason Reardon said in a statement that Watkins had been placed on administrative leave and stripped of his peace-officer powers.

summary:

title: City Of Fremont Hosts Census 2020 Kickoff Summit
summary:
From the City of Fremont:Posted on December 15, 2019The City of Fremont and Mayor Lily Mei hosted the Census 2020 Kickoff Summit on December 10, 2019 at Fremont City Hall.
As Census 2020 approaches, this meeting served as a springboard to present an overview of the importance of Census 2020 for the Fremont community and to provide for a strategy building session between leaders from community-based organizations, faith-based organizations, the business community, and elected officials to ensure that each Fremont resident is counted.
Census 2020 presents new challenges as the first digital Census and an increased public fear of the federal government.
The City of Fremont will use the information gathered at the Kickoff Summit to inform Census outreach activities and will continue reaching out to community organizations to serve as a resource and partner when the Census count begins in March 2020.
For more information about the City's Census 2020 efforts, contact Management Analyst Amanda Gallo by email or 510-284-4016.

To be considered for the list, companies submitted an application detailing over 200 data points describing their HR programs and practices.

title: Some California cities suspend public records requests because of coronavirus
authors: Ben Poston Is An Investigative Reporter Specializing In Data At The Los Angeles Times.
summary:
Some local governments in California are halting their responses to public records requests as they deal with staffing restrictions caused by the coronavirus outbreak.
The city of Fresno suspended “immediate responses” to public records requests on Tuesday after the city declared a state of emergency, according to an email from the city attorney’s office.
The city will need an additional 45 days to respond to records requests after the order is lifted, the email said.
Reporters across the country are seeing more and more of this: government agencies indefinitely delaying public records requests because of #coronavirus #COVID19 #FOIAI've seen:DallasFresnoHawaiiAnd now Fremont, CAJournos: where else have you received a similar response?

by Thomson ReutersBy Nick CareyDETROIT (Reuters) - U.S. new vehicle sales likely drove off a cliff in March as the coronavirus pandemic pounded consumer confidence and shuttered dealerships across much of the country, and sales are likely to take a further beating in April as social distancing guidelines remain in place.
TrueCar has forecast a sales drop for March of 37 percent and Lyman said sales in April could also be off between 50 percent to 60 percent.
Most major automakers, including General Motors Co and Toyota Motor Corp <7203.T>, are due to report quarterly U.S. sales on April 1.
IHS Markit estimates the coronavirus pandemic will cut full-year 2020 sales by 15.3 percent and globally sales will fall 12 percent - "considerably worse" than the fall in sales during the Great Recession in 2008-2009.
More dealers are embracing online sales, which could help mitigate falling sales.

title: Automakers to Close Factories in North America
summary:
With fear of infection rising among factory workers, and few customers shopping for cars, several automakers on Wednesday decided to idle their plants in the United States, Canada and Mexico for at least a week.
The decisions will put tens of thousands of people out of work and add to the coronavirus outbreak’s growing economic toll.
The country’s largest automakers — General Motors, Ford Motor and Fiat Chrysler — decided to close plants after the United Auto Workers union pressured them to do so to protect workers.
In addition to G.M., Ford and Fiat Chrysler, Honda, Toyota and Nissan also said they would idle their North American factories.

title: City Of Fremont Hosts Census 2020 Kickoff Summit
summary:
From the City of Fremont:Posted on December 15, 2019The City of Fremont and Mayor Lily Mei hosted the Census 2020 Kickoff Summit on December 10, 2019 at Fremont City Hall.
As Census 2020 approaches, this meeting served as a springboard to present an overview of the importance of Census 2020 for the Fremont community and to provide for a strategy building session between leaders from community-based organizations, faith-based organizations, the business community, and elected officials to ensure that each Fremont resident is counted.
Census 2020 presents new challenges as the first digital Census and an increased public fear of the federal government.
The City of Fremont will use the information gathered at the Kickoff Summit to inform Census outreach activities and will continue reaching out to community organizations to serve as a resource and partner when the Census count begins in March 2020.
For more information about the City's Census 2020 efforts, contact Management Analyst Amanda Gallo by email or 510-284-4016.

"These recommendations are meant to slow the spread of the virus in order to protect the health of Alameda County residents, particularly the elderly and people who have underlying medical conditions," she said.

summary:

The collision, at the Dumbarton Bridge toll plaza, was reported at 1:48 p.m., reportedly between a blue sedan and a toll booth, according to preliminary CHP logs.
An ambulance was called to the scene.
The 4 and 5 lanes were closed as of 2:10 p.m., and a traffic alert was issued, advising drivers to expect delays and use alternate routes.
There was no timetable for when the roadway would be reopened.

title: Bay Area shoppers raid stores in response to the coronavirus pandemic
summary:
FREMONT, Calif. (KRON) — As fears surrounding coronavirus spread around the world, here in the Bay Area basic necessities are selling out in the event of this pandemic.
Worried shoppers continue stocking up on food and other essentials leaving some store shelves empty.
Shoppers throughout the Bay Area were out in force, but stores can barely keep up with demand.
From the pasta aisle to hand sanitizer — empty shelves remain as people stock up on items, bracing for the unknown as fears surrounding coronavirus spread around the Bay Area and beyond.
People stocked up on bottled water, paper goods and non perishable items.

title: Fremont Police Arrest Man, Seize Gun
summary:
FREMONT, CA — Fremont Police officers arrested a 35-year-old man for several warrants on Saturday.
As they were making the arrest at a residence on Bell Street, next to the Fremont Hub, officers seized a gun and ammo.
Police say that everyone there was prohibited from possessing a gun.
An investigation into the incident continues.

title: Former Centerville Fire Station Building For Sale
summary:
The offer to sell the fire station building is in fulfillment of a Mitigation Measure of SiliconSage Builder's mixed use project that was approved by the City Council on March 19, 2019.
(View Item 5A under Scheduled Items for SiliconSage Centerville Mixed-Use Project on the City Council Meeting Agenda.)
The approved project includes demolishing existing buildings on an approximate 4.5 acre site to construct a multi-story building of 93 rental apartment units, including a number of affordable rental housing units, over 26,000 square feet of retail ground floor space in a mixed-use building along Fremont Boulevard, and 72 residential townhouse units at the rear of the mixed-use building along Jason Way.
Should you be interested in purchasing and moving the fire station building, please call Shaivali Desai of SiliconSage Builders at 408-630-0923 or send an email.
The offer to sell the fire station building will end sixty (60) days from January 21, 2020, which is on March 21, 2020 at 5:00 pm.

title: 2020 Primary Election: Dublin, Alameda County Voter Guide
summary:
DUBLIN, CA — With some 920,000 Alameda County voters registered ahead of the 2020 presidential primary Election Day on Tuesday, March 3, Dublin voters are poised to decide whether to raise the county sales tax, vote for a city schools bond measure, and vote for candidates running in county, state and federal races.
Nearly eight in ten Alameda County voters cast absentee ballots in the 2018 primary election, county records show.
Measure CMeasure C would increase the Alameda County sales tax by a half-cent for 20 years and raise an estimated $150 million per year.
Zone 7 Water AgencyFive candidates are vying to serve Alameda County on the Zone 7 Board of Directors.
Stay tuned to Patch as Election Day votes are counted in Alameda County and throughout California.

title: Who Will Serve Dublin, Fremont, Livermore? ALCO District 1 Debate
summary:
ALAMEDA COUNTY, CA — One of the most important political debates impacting Alameda County residents living in the cities of Dublin, Livermore, Fremont and nearby unincorporated areas happens Jan. 12, 2020.
For more than two decades, the District 1 seat on the Alameda County Board of Supervisors has been held by the same man.
Current District 1 Supervisor Scott Haggerty announced earlier this year he will not seek re-election when his current term expires in January 2021.
The long-time supervisor has held the post since November 1996 and is serving his sixth (and final) four-year term.
Fremont City Councilmember Vinnie Baker, Dublin Mayor David Haubert, Dublin City Councilmember Melissa Hernandez, and District 10 State Senator Bob Wieckowski are the four candidates on the March 3, 2020 Presidential Primary Election ballot vying for the District 1 seat.

title: Endorsements pulled for San Jose City Council candidate Jim Zito after divorce details go public
authors: Maggie Angst Covers Government On The Peninsula For The Mercury News. She'S A Chicago Native
Previously Covered Breaking News For The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
Education For The Island Packet In Hilton Head
John Woolfolk Is A Reporter For The Bay Area News Group
Based At The Mercury News. A Native Of New Orleans
He Grew Up Near San Jose. He Is A Graduate Of The Uc Berkeley School Of Journalism
summary:
City leaders are pulling their endorsements of San Jose City Council candidate Jim Zito in the wake of publicity surrounding his 2007 divorce case, during which his ex-wife accused him of being overly controlling and emotionally abusive toward her and their daughters.
By Wednesday morning, Liccardo, Foley, SVO PAC and the county’s Association of Realtors had all rescinded their endorsements of Zito.
San Jose Police Officers Association President Paul Kelly, whose organization first obtained copies of the divorce papers and used them as part of attack ads, commended the endorsement withdrawals.
The anti-Zito website launched by the association features a GIF of a red-headed Zito with smoke blowing out of his ears and head exploding.
Zito told this news organization the selected court documents that were released only told part of the story and the judge later tossed the demand for an anger management course.

title: City Of Fremont Rent Review Ordinance
summary:
From the City of Fremont:March 1, 2020The City of Fremont Rent Review Ordinance provides a review process for rent increases.
While the rent review process is non-binding, the City believes that the rent review process will contribute to fair and equitable resolutions for both parties by providing a neutral setting for discussion.
On Tuesday, February 18, 2020, the Fremont City Council approved the 2019 Rent Review Ordinance Annual Report.
The Ordinance has been amended so that landlords who own four or less residential rental units in Fremont are exempt from the Annual Rent Review Fee.
To view the 2019 Annual Rent Review Ordinance Report and for more information on the Ordinance visit our webpage.

title: CA Hits Fuel Tax Jackpot: Here's How Much Fremont Gets
summary:
SB1 also imposed an additional 20-cents-per-gallon tax on diesel fuel in addition to increasing the sales tax on diesel by 1.75 percent and raising annual vehicle registration fees ranging from $25 to $175.
Where did all this new fuel tax revenue go?
Between January 2018 and last June 30, Caltrans received about $2.8 billion in SB1 gas tax revenues alone.
The agency collected millions more from the increased diesel fuel tax and the attendant diesel fuel sales tax increase.
Fremont Public Works Director Hans Larsen told Patch, "The SB1 gas tax program is providing Fremont with approximately $4.0 million annually.

title: Best CA Cities To Find A Job In 2020
summary:
CALIFORNIA — If your New Year's resolution is to find a new job, California is one of the best places to make that happen in 2020, according to a new report by WalletHub.
San Francisco is the best city in California for jobs in 2020, according to the personal finance website.
Nine cities in the state ranked among the top 50 best cities for jobs in 2020, including Huntington Beach, Rancho Cucamonga, San Diego, Irvine, Sacramento and Garden Grove.
Scottsdale, Arizona, ranked as the best city in the country to find a job in 2020, according to WalletHub, followed by South Burlington, Vermont.
A number of California cities also ranked at the bottom of the list.

title: Tesla Model Y are starting to show up en masse at the Fremont factory, ready for car carriers
summary:
Tesla has begun preparations for the first set of Model Y deliveries that are scheduled to take place as early as March 15.
Car carriers loaded with Tesla’s all-electric crossover were spotted over the weekend alongside a stockpile of Model Y at the company’s factory lot in Fremont, California.
Tesla began a limited production run of the Model Y from its Fremont factory in January or roughly ten months after building its first prototype.
The Model Y initially had a fall 2020 production timeline which was later moved up to the summer of 2020.
Tesla is expected to deliver the first Model Y to customers on March 15.

title: PG&E Cuts Power To Thousands In East Bay
summary:
EAST BAY —Nearly 24 hours after PG&E originally expected to begin a Public Safety Power Shutoff, or PSPS, the power was finally cut to tens of thousands of East Bay customers.
The second phase of PG&E's shutdown and de-energizing started around 10:15 p.m. Wednesday, PG&E officials said.
The Fremont Police Department tweeted, "A very small area traversing Niles Canyon is affected by the planned power shutoff.
Even homes and businesses with solar lost power.
"When PG&E restores power, rooftop solar systems should re-engage automatically," PG&E officials said in a statement.

title: Pushed Back: Fremont's PG&E Power Shutoff
summary:
FREMONT, CA — PG&E announced Tuesday evening that it is moving forward with a Public Safety Power Shutoff, or PSPS.
Almost 75,000 East Bay homes and businesses are expected to have their power shut off starting around noon on Wednesday, Oct. 9.
The outage is planned because the strongest winds in two years are expected to tear through the Bay Area, raising the risk of wildfires.
PG&E plans to inspect its power lines before re-energizing them.

title: Fremont Power Outage Update: PG&E, Police, City Updates
summary:
EAST BAY — PG&E's Public Safety Power Shutoff, or PSPS, has been delayed.
The company told one East Bay city that the PSPS will now begin at 8 p.m. Wednesday.
The shutoff is expected to last through tomorrow, because of high winds that could combine with power lines to spark a wildfire.
But once the high winds have calmed, it could take PG&E days to re-energize all power lines, as the public utility company has announced plans to inspect all power lines before putting them in use.

title: Chase Through Fremont Results In Assault Suspect's Arrest
summary:
FREMONT, CA — A police chase through Fremont on Tuesday resulted in a man's arrest on suspicion of assault and weapons charges, one day after he had eluded officers trying to pursue him, according to police.
Marquice McClinton, 33, didn't pull over when officers tried to stop him on Monday, according to the Fremont Police Department.
At 7:46 a.m. Tuesday, officers tried to pull McClinton over, but he led police on a six-minute pursuit along city streets, according to police.
McClinton was medically cleared at a hospital and arrested on suspicion of multiple weapons violations, assault with a deadly weapon and evading.
The collision and subsequent investigation briefly shut down all eastbound lanes on Mowry between Paseo Padre Parkway and Civic.

title: 2 Suspects At Large In Violent Robbery At Fremont Walmart: Police
summary:
FREMONT, CA — Two men accused of violently robbing a woman in the parking lot of a Walmart in Fremont on Sunday are being sought by police, the Fremont Police Department said Sunday.
The suspects, described as two Hispanic men, shoved a woman to the ground and dragged her across the parking lot while she held onto her purse, according to police.
The suspects took the purse and fled in a black BMW, police said.

FREMONT — Two ex-convicts and a woman suspected of driving the stolen getaway car, have been identified as the three people arrested and charged in the Oct. 21 robbery of the Provident Credit Union, according to authorities and court records.
Colston has been charged with second-degree robbery and resisting arrest.
Crawford, who has a 2013 felony assault with a firearm conviction that he went to prison for, has been charged with second degree robbery.
According to court documents, Colston and Crawford entered the credit union together and as Crawford stood look-out, Colston approached a teller and presented a note demanding money.

title: Fremont to clamp down on ‘out of control’ real estate open house signs
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — They’re the silent scourge of Fremont — open house signs that clutter street corners and sidewalks every weekend, sometimes before dawn and well into the evening hours.
Now, after years of hearing residents complain, city officials plan to clamp down on real estate agents who plant the signs in strategic locations to get a leg up on the competition.
There are no rules limiting the number of signs a real estate agent can put up, and officials say a few of them are taking advantage of the vacuum.
A key to his business plan is to “pepper the city” with open house signs each weekend, Crofton said.
And they would love to see that end,” he said of other real estate agents and brokers.

title: After 40 years, Minerva’s restaurant is closing in Fremont
authors: Linda Zavoral Is A Features Editor
Blogger For The Bay Area News Group. She Blogs For Eat Drink Play
summary:
Diners have just a few days to get into Minerva’s, a Fremont institution, for a hearty breakfast or one of the restaurant’s signature sandwiches that for 40 years have been served stuffed into freshly baked pitas.
The Centerville district restaurant is scheduled to close at the end of business Thursday, Oct. 3, with development plans in the works for this stretch of Fremont Boulevard.
Many of Minerva’s recipes — particularly her cinnamon rolls and pita bread — are legendary in Fremont.
At 3 a.m., she would start baking.
Details: Minerva’s will serve from 7:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. on its last three days — today, Wednesday and Thursday — at 37463 Fremont Blvd, Fremont.

title: Groundbreaking Held For Fremont Event Center, Plaza
summary:
FREMONT, CA — Fremont is getting a new Downtown Event Center and Plaza.
The City considers this a big milestone in creating an active, vibrant downtown that will serve as a central gathering location in the Fremont community.
The Event Center will have meeting rooms, a large lobby, a catering kitchen, and more for networking, local business gatherings, and conferences.
The building will be Fremont's first all-electric building with zero dependence on fossil fuels, and will also feature commissioned artwork.
The outdoor plaza will have a lawn, multipurpose space, a designated area for food trucks, and a garden breakout space under a canopy of trees.

title: City Of Fremont Hosts Census 2020 Kickoff Summit
summary:
From the City of Fremont:Posted on December 15, 2019The City of Fremont and Mayor Lily Mei hosted the Census 2020 Kickoff Summit on December 10, 2019 at Fremont City Hall.
As Census 2020 approaches, this meeting served as a springboard to present an overview of the importance of Census 2020 for the Fremont community and to provide for a strategy building session between leaders from community-based organizations, faith-based organizations, the business community, and elected officials to ensure that each Fremont resident is counted.
Census 2020 presents new challenges as the first digital Census and an increased public fear of the federal government.
The City of Fremont will use the information gathered at the Kickoff Summit to inform Census outreach activities and will continue reaching out to community organizations to serve as a resource and partner when the Census count begins in March 2020.
For more information about the City's Census 2020 efforts, contact Management Analyst Amanda Gallo by email or 510-284-4016.

authors: Thy Vo Covers Government In Santa Clara County

summary:
FREMONT — Southbound Paseo Padre in Fremont has been reopened, after being briefly closed due to a vehicle collision that caused major injuries, according to the Fremont Police Department.
The department initially warned motorists around 4 p.m. to avoid the road until 7 p.m, but the road was reopened within an hour.
It’s unclear at this time what caused the crash and how many people were injured.

summary:

Power is being shut off to nearly 800,000 Pacific Gas & Electric customers in Northern California due to the threat of wildfires, and in some areas, officials declared emergencies and curfews to deal with the blackouts.
Windy conditions can cause power lines to spark fires when they are blown down, or to come into contact with trees or other vegetation.
PG&E power lines have been blamed for several high profile fires in recent years, including the blaze that killed 86 people last year in Paradise, California.
PG & E, which announced the deliberate outage, is working to prevent a repeat of a catastrophe last November in which faulty power lines it owned were determined to have sparked California's deadliest wildfire in modern history.

summary:
FREMONT, CA — A motorcyclist who was killed in a collision with an SUV in Fremont on Wednesday evening was identified by the Alameda County coroner's bureau on Thursday as 29-year-old Joel Vieto of Fremont.
The collision occurred on Stevenson Boulevard between Fremont Boulevard and Paseo Padre Parkway at about 7 p.m. Wednesday and Vieto was pronounced dead at the scene, police said.
The SUV driver, a 44-year-old Fremont man, wasn't hurt in the collision but a female passenger suffered injuries to her leg and was transported to a hospital for treatment, according to Fremont police spokeswoman Geneva Bosques.
The SUV driver remained at the scene and cooperated with police, Bosques said.
It doesn't appear that alcohol or drugs were factors in the collision, according to Bosques.

PG&E Shutdown Info – Community and DistrictPOSSIBLE PG&E POWER SHUT OFFS FAQWhat are preventive power shutoffs?
California's investor-owned electric utilities, including PG&E, may shut off electric power, referred to as "de-energization" or Public Safety Power Shut-offs (PSPS), to protect public safety.
In the PSPS program, power may be cut on transmission and distribution lines in ﬁre-prone areas when the risk of wildﬁre is deemed to be high.
Due to the interconnected nature of the power grid, any electricity customer may be affected by power shutoffs, even customers in urban areas.
Schools and colleges may declare that a campus will close as soon as they receive an advance PSPS notice, to provide students and their families as much notice as possible.

title: Was the Fremont California slender salamander playing possum?
authors: Wildlife Columnist For The Bay Area News Group. She Also Writes About Gardening
Is The Founder Of Our Garden
A Demonstration Garden In Walnut Creek. Morris Started Her Career In As A Reporter For A Small New Mexico Newspaper. She Has Lived In The Bay Area Since
summary:
With that being said, at around 7 p.m. recently, I went outside to throw the garbage out.
It was a California slender salamander, and it didn’t look alive.
After searching, I found it a few inches away under a leaf with just its head sticking out.
(After) searching online, I surmised that it was playing dead or was potentially too cold.
The California slender salamander doesn’t play dead when faced with danger, but it does go into a sort of hibernation (it’s called aestivation) from May through October in order to avoid the hotter, dryer months.

title: Rabid Bat Found In Fremont
summary:
FREMONT, CA — A bat found in Fremont's Northgate area last weekend has tested positive for rabies, police said.
Fremont police Animal Services responded to a home in the area of Chaucer Drive and Atteridge Court on Sunday and retrieved a dead bat from a driveway, authorities said.
However, Fremont police said that as far as they know there was no contact between the bat and another animal or human.
In addition, they said they have not received any other similar reports and the last rabid bat case reported in Fremont was in 2015.
They said anyone whose pet touched the bat should call Fremont Animal Services at (510) 790-6630 as well as their veterinarian.

title: Millions Facing Blackouts In Unprecedented Preventive PG&E Power Shutoffs
summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (CBS SF) — With red flag warning conditions packing howling winds predicted for late Saturday, Pacific Gas & Electric officials went forward with the second planned power shutoff this week because of mounting fire danger conditions from the Bay Area to the Sierra.
Pacific Gas & Electric said the blackouts began around 2 p.m. Saturday in parts of 36 counties.
It’s the third preventative shutoff in as many weeks amid concern that gusty winds could knock down power lines and spark fires.
“We have revisted and adjusted some of our standards and protocols to determining when we will deenergize a high voltage transmission line,” said PG&E president Andy Vesey.
PG&E officials confirmed some are having their power shut off when they don’t necessarily live in an area impacted by high fire danger or winds.

title: Fremont Looks to Add More Microgrids in Era of Wildfire Power Shutoffs
summary:
About two years ago, Fremont installed microgrids at three of its fire stations.
The city buys the power under contract from Gridscape, a company based in Fremont that installed, owns and operates the microgrids.
Fremont signed the power purchase agreement with Gridscape in mid-2016 and deployed the microgrids in December 2017.
The three microgrids cost Fremont $2.4 million of which the commission contributed $1.8 million through its grant program for microgrids.
Often critical facilities have backup power, usually diesel generators, but what people often fail to realize, says Gore, is that it can be difficult to replenish fuel supplies when power is out.

authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont

summary:
The city’s new mobility commission is the culmination of an effort started nearly two and a half years ago by Mayor Lily Mei.
At that time, the Fremont City Council established a mobility task force, instead of a full commission.
The task force recommended the creation of a mobility commission, with its key charge to put in place the action plan — which the City Council approved in March.
The City Council unanimously voted Tuesday to form the commission.
However, city staff reports now say the Mobility Commission won’t add to the city’s expenses, as it will replace the city’s current bicycle and pedestrian technical advisory committee.

title: Rare Friday The 13th Full Moon To Fill California Skies
summary:
CALIFORNIA — Friday the 13th is a little extra spooky this year, as a rare Harvest Moon will appear in the night sky across America on Friday, Sept. 13.
The Harvest Moon name refers to the full moon closest to the autumnal equinox — on Friday, Sept. 13, the moon will reach the farthest point of its orbit around the Earth, and thus be at its most visible.
In California, the full moon on Friday the 13th happened at 7 a.m.
The Harvest Moon will appear full from Thursday night through Sunday morning, according to NASA.
The actual autumnal equinox will take place on Sept. 23 at 3:50 a.m., which marks the end of summer and beginning of fall.

title: City Of Fremont's Christmas Tree Composting Procedure
summary:
Reduce the environmental impact of the holiday season by planting a live tree, decorating with a reusable tree, or properly composting a live tree.
Christmas trees are only compostable if they are free of all decorations, tinsel, nails, and tree stands (including wooden stands nailed to the bottom of the trunk).
If your tree is less than 6 feet in length, place the whole tree in the gutter on your collection day.
If your tree is over 6 feet in length, cut the tree in half and place both halves in the gutter on your collection day.
Place the black garbage cart at the curb on your scheduled collection day.

title: Fremont Man ID'd Following Deadly Crash
summary:
FREMONT, CA — A motorcyclist who was killed in a collision with an SUV in Fremont on Wednesday evening was identified by the Alameda County coroner's bureau on Thursday as 29-year-old Joel Vieto of Fremont.
The collision occurred on Stevenson Boulevard between Fremont Boulevard and Paseo Padre Parkway at about 7 p.m. Wednesday and Vieto was pronounced dead at the scene, police said.
The SUV driver, a 44-year-old Fremont man, wasn't hurt in the collision but a female passenger suffered injuries to her leg and was transported to a hospital for treatment, according to Fremont police spokeswoman Geneva Bosques.
The SUV driver remained at the scene and cooperated with police, Bosques said.
It doesn't appear that alcohol or drugs were factors in the collision, according to Bosques.

title: California's homeless census was already troubled. Covid-19 is making it impossible
summary:
With no fixed address and little trust in the government, the homeless population has always been notoriously difficult to track.
While the census falls under the umbrella of the federal Census Bureau in Washington, jurisdictions have the option to form their own committees to work with the regional offices – something the federal bureau has recommended.
Before the coronavirus crisis, the federal Census Bureau planned on counting people experiencing homelessness from 30 March to 1 April.
Photograph: Maria, census regional manager“We have shared the operational plans provided by the US Census Bureau with the homeless service providers and advocates in our community,” the letter reads.

title: Fremont spending $150,000 on radar signs that will track your speed
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — In an attempt to slow down drivers on major roads and near schools, Fremont is doubling down on radar speed signs, spending nearly $150,000 to add 30 more to the city’s arsenal.
Fremont already has 14 speed signs that it installed incrementally through September.
The Fremont City Council unanimously approved the bulk purchase of the additional signs at a meeting earlier this month.
Currently, public works department staff analyzes the speed data sent to the city every 15 minutes, but police don’t have access to the real-time data.
City staff hopes to install the first five new signs by the end of January and the rest by the middle of next year.

title: Fremont Power Outage Update: PG&E, Police, City Updates

The company told one East Bay city that the PSPS will now begin at 8 p.m. Wednesday.
The shutoff is expected to last through tomorrow, because of high winds that could combine with power lines to spark a wildfire.
But once the high winds have calmed, it could take PG&E days to re-energize all power lines, as the public utility company has announced plans to inspect all power lines before putting them in use.

2019 Homeless Point-in-Time Count and Survey has recently been completed.
Notably, the report reveals that Fremont's homeless population increased by 27% since the 2017 Point-in-Time Count, and the number of unsheltered persons rose from 282 to 485.
For the first time, the survey provided a breakdown of where unsheltered people sleep; approximately 40% of Fremont's homeless population lives in an RV or car.
In addition, 43% of Fremont's homeless population was also seeking basic sanitation, a need that is now starting to be addressed by Fremont's CleanStart Mobile Hygiene Unit.

The finding may be surprising, considering the notoriety of Bay Area housing prices as a whole.

The initial leasing transactions by Facebook in Fremont included 14 buildings totaling 750,000 square feet that Facebook rented from Peery Arrilaga and 290,000 square feet in three buildings the tech titan leased from Sobrato Organization.

title: Flavored Tobacco Ban Takes Effect In Fremont
summary:
FREMONT, CA — New regulations surrounding the sale of tobacco products have taken effect in Fremont, including a ban on flavored tobacco products.
The ban took effect on Friday, along with other features of the city's Tobacco Retail License Program.
The program was passed unanimously by the Fremont City Council with the community joining over 150 other California municipalities with similar programs.
The flavored products ban includes menthol cigarettes and flavored non-cigarette tobacco products such as little cigars, smokeless tobacco, and flavored components of e-cigarettes and vaping devices.
In a release, the City of Fremont said, "The Council's action is intended to address the public health epidemic of vaping by deterring youth access to any tobacco products in an effort to prevent future generations from nicotine addiction."

title: City Of Fremont Hosts Census 2020 Kickoff Summit
summary:
From the City of Fremont:Posted on December 15, 2019The City of Fremont and Mayor Lily Mei hosted the Census 2020 Kickoff Summit on December 10, 2019 at Fremont City Hall.
As Census 2020 approaches, this meeting served as a springboard to present an overview of the importance of Census 2020 for the Fremont community and to provide for a strategy building session between leaders from community-based organizations, faith-based organizations, the business community, and elected officials to ensure that each Fremont resident is counted.
Census 2020 presents new challenges as the first digital Census and an increased public fear of the federal government.
The City of Fremont will use the information gathered at the Kickoff Summit to inform Census outreach activities and will continue reaching out to community organizations to serve as a resource and partner when the Census count begins in March 2020.
For more information about the City's Census 2020 efforts, contact Management Analyst Amanda Gallo by email or 510-284-4016.

Other notes from Gonzales:Delivering safe drinking water to the cities of Fremont, Newark and Union City is our highest priority and has been for over a century.
Each May 1 we release our annual water quality report that provides the results of the thousands of analyses conducted on our drinking water - in all cases, our drinking water standards met or surpassed state and federal drinking water standards.
The water group does offer information, though, on filtering technologies that you can use to dramatically reduce water contamination.

title: Homicide Charges Filed In Fremont Bar Fight Death
summary:

Matthew Jardine faces a charge of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Thaddeus Steiner, also of Fremont, outside the Florence Bar on Niles Boulevard.
Police said Sunday that, during the fight, Steiner was "struck in the head by Jardine's fist," and went to the ground.
Fremont Fire Department paramedics, unaware there had been a fight, found Steiner lying on the ground in the courtyard, suffering from a head injury.
Since the incident occurred, detectives have kept the Alameda County District Attorney apprised of the case, and had to ultimately wait for the Alameda County Coroner's autopsy report to be finalized before concluding the criminal investigation."

Atkins was struck by a vehicle in the 39200 block of Paseo Padre Parkway in front of the Gateway Plaza mall at about 11:50 p.m. on Aug. 18 and died at the scene before he could be transported to a hospital, police said.
An 18-year-old Fremont woman who was driving the vehicle that struck Atkins was cooperative with investigators, who don't suspect that intoxication was a factor in the collision, according to police.
The collision was the fourth fatal collision on Fremont city streets so far this year.

title: Climate Strike In Fremont Friday: What You Need To Know
summary:
FREMONT, CA — In an effort to draw greater attention to the global climate crisis, youth from around the world and across the United States will stage a strike on Friday, Sept. 20 to demand an end to fossil fuels and reductions in corporate pollution and environmental destruction.
The event is expected to be one of the largest environmental protests ever.
Millions of people are expected to walk out of their schools, workplaces, and homes in solidarity, and organizers in Fremont have scheduled the strike to take place on Friday, Sept. 20 at 3:30 p.m. at 4375 Blue Ridge Street, Fremont, 94536.
The international protest comes days before the United Nations Climate Action Summit taking place on Sept. 23 in New York City, where leaders from government, business, and civil society are expected to address the global climate emergency.
"Together, we will sound the alarm and show our politicians that business as usual is no longer an option," reads the official Global Climate Strike Page.

title: One Dead, 2 Hurt in I-880 Crash In Fremont Saturday: CHP
summary:
FREMONT, CA — One man was killed and two other people injured in a two-vehicle accident on Interstate Freeway 880 in Fremont Saturday night, the California Highway Patrol said.
The CHP received a report at 6:36 p.m. Saturday of a Tesla sedan rear-ending a Ford Ranger pickup truck on northbound I-880 between Mowry Avenue and Stevenson Boulevard in Fremont, CHP Officer Manuel Leal said.
A passenger in the Ranger was then ejected from that vehicle, Leal said; the drivers of the two vehicles were also injured, he said.
One man was taken to Stanford Hospital, where he died from his injuries.
The other two people, Leal said, were taken to Eden Medical Center in Castro Valley for treatment of their injuries.

title: Tesla suspends production at U.S. vehicle factory due to coronavirus
summary:
(Reuters) - Tesla Inc said on Thursday it will suspend production at its San Francisco Bay Area vehicle factory on March 24, ending a standoff with California authorities concerned about the spread of the coronavirus.
The company said its New York solar roof tile factory also will temporarily suspend production, while operations at its Nevada battery plant will continue.
The decision to suspend production at the Fremont, California, plant comes as Tesla ramps up production of its Model Y sport utility vehicle at the factory.
The county sheriff’s office said on Tuesday afternoon Tesla was not considered an essential business and cannot continue to operate its factory normally.
Tesla said on Thursday it would continue basic operations at the Fremont factory in compliance with the order to support vehicle and energy services and charging infrastructure.

title: Fremont Named The Bay Area's Safest City For 2019
summary:
Wallet Hub, a site that has previously named Fremont, California as America's happiest city, America's least-stressed city, one of America's least-sinful cities several years running has now ranked the Alameda County city as the Bay Area's safest for 2019.
Here’s an easy way to know if your city protects you from life’s hazards:https://t.co/TwqFzzU10y pic.twitter.com/F9jSRXAG3Y — WalletHub (@wallethub) December 2, 2019No California city made the list until #29 with Irvine being named the state's safest, Fremont was right behind at #30 out of 200 cities in the study.
Wallet Hub took into account law enforcement per capita, traffic fatalities, unemployment rates, natural disaster risks, assaults, hate crimes and more to come up with their results.
Santa Rosa came in at #59 safest, San Jose at #83, San Francisco at #145 & Oakland at #149.
The safest city in America for 2019, per their study, is Columbia, Maryland and the least safest is St. Louis, Missouri.

title: City Of Fremont Hosts Census 2020 Kickoff Summit
summary:
From the City of Fremont:Posted on December 15, 2019The City of Fremont and Mayor Lily Mei hosted the Census 2020 Kickoff Summit on December 10, 2019 at Fremont City Hall.
As Census 2020 approaches, this meeting served as a springboard to present an overview of the importance of Census 2020 for the Fremont community and to provide for a strategy building session between leaders from community-based organizations, faith-based organizations, the business community, and elected officials to ensure that each Fremont resident is counted.
Census 2020 presents new challenges as the first digital Census and an increased public fear of the federal government.
The City of Fremont will use the information gathered at the Kickoff Summit to inform Census outreach activities and will continue reaching out to community organizations to serve as a resource and partner when the Census count begins in March 2020.
For more information about the City's Census 2020 efforts, contact Management Analyst Amanda Gallo by email or 510-284-4016.

title: Fremont to clamp down on ‘out of control’ real estate open house signs
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — They’re the silent scourge of Fremont — open house signs that clutter street corners and sidewalks every weekend, sometimes before dawn and well into the evening hours.
Now, after years of hearing residents complain, city officials plan to clamp down on real estate agents who plant the signs in strategic locations to get a leg up on the competition.
There are no rules limiting the number of signs a real estate agent can put up, and officials say a few of them are taking advantage of the vacuum.
A key to his business plan is to “pepper the city” with open house signs each weekend, Crofton said.
And they would love to see that end,” he said of other real estate agents and brokers.

title: Home Invasion Suspect in Custody After Barricading Himself in Fremont Rooftop
summary:
A home invasion suspect is in custody Friday after barricading himself for hours on top of a five-story building under construction in Fremont's Warm Springs neighborhood.
Police around 10:30 a.m. surrounded the area of Warm Springs Boulevard and Brown Road and began negotiating with the suspect, who during the standoff threw construction materials down toward officers.
"The suspect confronted the homeowner and then ran out of the house," said Geneva Bosques, Fremont police spokesperson.
Police said the female victim in the home invasion robbery was assaulted by the suspect.
At 5:33 p.m., Fremont police said in a tweet that the man was ready to comply and, "was just safely taken into custody."

title: Fremont spending $150,000 on radar signs that will track your speed
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — In an attempt to slow down drivers on major roads and near schools, Fremont is doubling down on radar speed signs, spending nearly $150,000 to add 30 more to the city’s arsenal.
Fremont already has 14 speed signs that it installed incrementally through September.
The Fremont City Council unanimously approved the bulk purchase of the additional signs at a meeting earlier this month.
Currently, public works department staff analyzes the speed data sent to the city every 15 minutes, but police don’t have access to the real-time data.
City staff hopes to install the first five new signs by the end of January and the rest by the middle of next year.

title: City Of Fremont's Christmas Tree Composting Procedure
summary:
Reduce the environmental impact of the holiday season by planting a live tree, decorating with a reusable tree, or properly composting a live tree.
Christmas trees are only compostable if they are free of all decorations, tinsel, nails, and tree stands (including wooden stands nailed to the bottom of the trunk).
If your tree is less than 6 feet in length, place the whole tree in the gutter on your collection day.
If your tree is over 6 feet in length, cut the tree in half and place both halves in the gutter on your collection day.
Place the black garbage cart at the curb on your scheduled collection day.

summary:

The suspects, described as two Hispanic men, shoved a woman to the ground and dragged her across the parking lot while she held onto her purse, according to police.
The suspects took the purse and fled in a black BMW, police said.

title: Chase Through Fremont Results In Assault Suspect's Arrest
summary:
FREMONT, CA — A police chase through Fremont on Tuesday resulted in a man's arrest on suspicion of assault and weapons charges, one day after he had eluded officers trying to pursue him, according to police.
Marquice McClinton, 33, didn't pull over when officers tried to stop him on Monday, according to the Fremont Police Department.
At 7:46 a.m. Tuesday, officers tried to pull McClinton over, but he led police on a six-minute pursuit along city streets, according to police.
McClinton was medically cleared at a hospital and arrested on suspicion of multiple weapons violations, assault with a deadly weapon and evading.
The collision and subsequent investigation briefly shut down all eastbound lanes on Mowry between Paseo Padre Parkway and Civic.

title: ‘Can’t touch this’: Fremont council rejects hillside homes proposal
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — For the second time in about 30 years, a proposal to build more homes near the scenic Vineyard Hills neighborhood not too far from MC Hammer’s old abode has been shot down.
The planning commission rejected the plan in June and he appealed the decision to the council.
Chris Cavette, who doesn’t live nearby but said he supports residents hoping to preserve their views, told the council the planned district agreement clearly trumps Hundal’s proposal.
“Once a planned district is approved, that’s it, you can’t change it, it’s there forever,” he said.
“The hillside is one of those special places where we have to preserve,” Councilman Raj Salwan said.

title: Police in Fremont Arrest Suspect in San Mateo Parking Lot Shooting
summary:
Police in Fremont caught up to a suspect connected to a shooting in a San Mateo store parking lot Monday afternoon that left one person injured.
Fremont officers joined East Palo Alto police in a vehicle pursuit of the suspect that crossed the Dumbarton Bridge.
The suspect crashed at Thornton Avenue and Post and fled on foot before officers caught him and took him into custody, police said.
The suspect was identified only as a 21-year-old male from East Palo Alto.
Officers responded at 2:31 p.m. to the shooting reported in the area of the parking lot of the La Hacienda Market at 201 N. Amphlett Blvd.

title: Was the Fremont California slender salamander playing possum?
authors: Wildlife Columnist For The Bay Area News Group. She Also Writes About Gardening
Is The Founder Of Our Garden
A Demonstration Garden In Walnut Creek. Morris Started Her Career In As A Reporter For A Small New Mexico Newspaper. She Has Lived In The Bay Area Since
summary:
With that being said, at around 7 p.m. recently, I went outside to throw the garbage out.
It was a California slender salamander, and it didn’t look alive.
After searching, I found it a few inches away under a leaf with just its head sticking out.
(After) searching online, I surmised that it was playing dead or was potentially too cold.
The California slender salamander doesn’t play dead when faced with danger, but it does go into a sort of hibernation (it’s called aestivation) from May through October in order to avoid the hotter, dryer months.

title: Tesla to lay off workers cuts workers' salaries because of the corona virus
summary:
[ad_1](Reuters) – Tesla Inc (TSLA.O) told workers on Tuesday that it would lay off all non-essential workers and make pay cuts during a shutdown of U.S. manufacturing facilities due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Tesla employee salaries will be cut from April 13, and cuts will remain in effect through the end of the second quarter, the email said.
In the United States, employees' salaries are reduced by 10%, directors' salaries by 20%, and vice presidents' salaries by 30%.
Tesla ceased production in both plants last month after it ended its confrontation with authorities concerned about the spread of the corona virus.
The suspension interrupts a planned increase in the production of its model Y sports car at the factory.

title: Pushed Back: Fremont's PG&E Power Shutoff

Almost 75,000 East Bay homes and businesses are expected to have their power shut off starting around noon on Wednesday, Oct. 9.
The outage is planned because the strongest winds in two years are expected to tear through the Bay Area, raising the risk of wildfires.
PG&E plans to inspect its power lines before re-energizing them.

title: Van filled with dogs stolen in Fremont, recovered in Oakland
authors: Fiona Kelliher Is A Breaking News Reporter At The Mercury News. She Previously Covered Housing
Real Estate For The San Francisco Business Times. Originally Minneapolis
She Is A Fan Of Almost Any Food That Is Fried
Harry Harris Is A Pulitzer Prize Winning Breaking News Reporter For The Bay Area News Group. He Began His Oakland Tribune Career In September As A Copyboy. He Became A Reporter In
Is Considered One Of The Best Crime
summary:
FREMONT — A van filled with several dozen dogs stolen from a Fremont hotel parking lot overnight was tracked to East Oakland, where the suspected thief was arrested and the vehicle containing most of the canines recovered, police said.
Police put the final count at 24 dogs recovered from inside the van, saying that paperwork that was missing from inside the van prevented them from assessing exactly how many dogs were originally inside.
The recovered dogs were all taken to the Oakland Animal Shelter where they will be kept while Oakland and Fremont police investigate what happened and if any of the missing ones can be located.
He was arrested on suspicion of vehicle theft and theft of the dogs.

title: Rare Friday The 13th Full Moon To Fill California Skies
summary:
CALIFORNIA — Friday the 13th is a little extra spooky this year, as a rare Harvest Moon will appear in the night sky across America on Friday, Sept. 13.
The Harvest Moon name refers to the full moon closest to the autumnal equinox — on Friday, Sept. 13, the moon will reach the farthest point of its orbit around the Earth, and thus be at its most visible.
In California, the full moon on Friday the 13th happened at 7 a.m.
The Harvest Moon will appear full from Thursday night through Sunday morning, according to NASA.
The actual autumnal equinox will take place on Sept. 23 at 3:50 a.m., which marks the end of summer and beginning of fall.

title: The Cost of Vision Zero
summary:
The issue I am referring to is the Vision Zero project, which is tied in with the Fremont General Plan.
The Vision Zero initiative is the reason why we have all seen fundamental changes to the streets of Fremont.
Given the hundreds of millions of dollars spent nationally on Vision Zero, that seems a poor return on our investment.
So how much does Vision Zero cost?
American cities are spending millions of dollars on Vision Zero, with the result being an increase in the response times of services to life threatening emergencies and no measurable decrease in the number of fatalities that Vision Zero was intended to produce.

Out of the region’s population of 7 million, 2 million people live on top of the fault.

authors: Linda Zavoral Is A Features Editor
Blogger For The Bay Area News Group. She Blogs For Eat Drink Play
summary:
CLICK HERE if you are having trouble viewing these photos on a mobile deviceBay Area diners said farewell to a lot of beloved restaurants in 2019.
Here, in order of longevity, were 15 favorites that shut their doors from Daly City and San Jose to Crockett and Walnut Creek.
The last 12 years belonged to Julio Mercedes and Bernadette Aggen, who decided to retire in February — and retire the name and the recipes.
The Nantucket Restaurant operated from 1975 to 1993, after which the marina owners took over and called their place simply The Nantucket.
For nearly four decades, original owner Harriet Spier and later the Chan family baked decadent desserts for appreciative customers on the Peninsula and in the South Bay.

title: Fremont detectives crack 1982 double murder cold case using DNA testing
authors: Joseph Geha Is A Multimedia Journalist Covering Fremont
Newark For The Bay Area News Group. His Prior Work Has Been Seen In Multiple Bay Area Outlets
Kliv Radio. He Is A Graduate Of California State University
summary:
FREMONT — Using the same modern DNA testing that helped nab the suspected Golden State Killer, detectives in Fremont have solved a double murder case that’s been cold for 37 years.
While the bodies were both found in Fremont, police said it’s believed one or both of the murders happened in Milpitas.
In 2018, Blass, the department’s cold case homicide detective, took up the case and determined more information needed to be reviewed, and modern DNA testing could be used.
Police had more help from Serological Research Institute in Richmond, in extracting and testing DNA from Hudspeth’s remains, which confirmed him as the suspect in the case.
Last week, police said detectives met with the families of Atup and Malatag to share the new revelations in the murders case.
